content.text: is a system to generate user facing documentation from markup files (markdown only at the moment).
Documentation files seat next to your product codebase and are part of your product's SDLC.
provides directives to simplify your day-to-day documentation process as well as to improve maintenance in a long run.
Continue reading to learn more about
rationale
structuring your documentation
leveraging existing code snippets and test results
diagrams support
UI documentation techniques
presentation mode
extremely fast navigation
local search with auto preview
If you are reading this documentation for the first time, I suggest to read in the intended order
(there is a next button at the bottom of each page).
Feel free to use Table Of Contents on the left, or search (top right) otherwise.
Keeping documentation up-to-date is a hard task.
The further documentation is from the code the more likely it won't be updated when a feature is added or changed.
Depending on your product and clients, stale documentation effects are:
users' time lost
reputation damage
As part of your code review you check that there are:
no design violations
no subtle bugs
tests are updated
Now it is time to add to it
documentation is updated
If you want your users be happy you have to keep documentation in sync with you product. It takes time.
Not every change to the product is a new functionality. But it may still require a documentation update.
Here are some activities that most likely put your documentation out of sync:
moving UI elements around
renaming REST response fields
removing redundant command line parameters
renaming public API classes
This does not mean that we always have to copy-and-paste code snippets, REST responses and retaking screenshots.
Our code base already contains a wast amount of data. And some extra data can be created by running tests.
Here are some of the things that we can use to make a documentation automatically up-to-date:
examples of how to use API (part of code)
config files
test results
Web UI
REST
CLI
business logic
Doing copy-paste between sources takes time and is getting abandoned quickly.
What we can do instead is refer artifacts that are around code base.
Markdown uses ASCII to represent styles and page structure.
Example of how to keep your documentation up-to-date by referencing existing resource.
Note that this is
extension and is not part of a standard markdown syntax.
Mdoc comes with a command line tool that:
generates documentation website
runs auto-preview local server
runs documentation server
Optin
to add the command line to your hosts.
In your terminal execute
to make sure tool is available.
Execute
to create a minimum set of files for your documentation.
Navigate to the newly created directory. Execute
Open prompted url inside your browser.
Blue
eye
icon in the top right corner indicates that preview is on.
Open any text editor, modify and save
file.
Changes will be displayed in the browser.

file in its root.

All you have to do is indent your code with 4 spaces inside your markdown document and

We use highlightjs library to provide syntax highlighting
To make regular text more readable we maintain a narrow column of text. You code snippets however can't always follow the
same rules. In case of a wide code snippets we expand the horizontal boundaries and center the source code to fit.

content.text: To boost documentation maintainability you can refer text and code snippets from already existing files.
Include-dash family is our custom extension to markdown to support various scenarios.
File will be looked up using following rules:
directory with a markup file
root directory of a documentation
all lookup paths listed in a special file

Instead comments can be automatically extracted and presented as part of the text

content.text: Selecting a tab will switch all the tabs on every page.
Using
plugin a markdown content per tab can be specified. For example installation instructions
can be specified this way.
Each tab will display inlined markdown from specified files.

content.text: Annotated images automatically participate in presentation mode. Annotations appear one by one and scale to match the
zoom level of a presentation.
To render math you can use
latex
math expressions.
Surround latex expression with fenced block and specify

The result will be a following math expression.
Rendered expression also participates in presentation mode by automatically scaling up
NGINX stores every access to access.log. It kerberizes the request.
Log Stash runs on the same machine and consumes access.log lines.
As long as lines contain required information it gets processed.
Log stash won't write data directly to Elastic. Instead we will use Kafka as a buffer in front.
Another instance of Log Stash consumes records from Kafka queue and writes them to Elastic.
Need follow-up with ELK team to see if buffer is still required.
Finally data gets written to Elastic by LogStash. Access.log timestamp will be the primary timestamp of a record.
We have built a web app to display news consumption analytics. And URL is be accessible by everyone.
Most of the data we take from Elastic. Data grows very fast and we need to come up with a scalable approach.
CMDB departments, active users and potential other information we take from CMDB. We can't replicate this queries by simply using
out of the box Kibana interface
